questions.question: PA image. Which of the following is not present?
questions.learning_points:
The heart is enlarged (cardiomegaly). Visible artifacts include sternotomy wires, prosthetic heart valves, and a pacemaker.
There is no left internal jugular catheter in situ; its predicated position is indicated on the overlay image.

questions.question: Athletic 24-year-old female non-smoker with palpitations. Which statement is true?
options: Breast asymmetry indicates a previous mastectomy
questions.learning_points:
At first glance the lungs appear hyperexpanded, but this is an unlikely finding in a young and fit non-smoker.
The hemidiaphragm contours remain domed and the anterior ends of the 7th ribs intersect the mid-clavicular lines at or below the diaphragm.
The breasts are very slightly asymmetric; as they are in most normal subjects. Previous breast surgery is not a diagnosis made with an X-ray – ask the patient or check the notes.
Heart size is normal.
There are no visible rib fractures.

questions.question: Nasogastric tube insertion with failure of attempted aspiration of gastric fluid. What is the location of the nasogastric tube?
questions.learning_points:
Feeding through a misplaced nasogastric tube is considered a ‘never’ event.
This nasogastric tube has passed into the right lung; feeding in this position carries a high mortality risk.
Note the external wires, the right internal jugular catheter, and the bilateral perihilar and left lower zone consolidation.

questions.question: Middle-aged male with cough, high temperature and chest pain. Where is the acute abnormality?
questions.learning_points:
There is consolidation of the right lower zone. This could be in the right middle or lower lobes, but this will not change management in this patient with pneumonia.
Gas under the diaphragm is in the stomach and there is no history of an acute abdomen to suggest perforation.
Note there is a healed fracture of the left clavicle – not an acute abnormality.

questions.question: A chest X-ray taken one hour earlier showed a large right pneumothorax.  A chest drain was inserted, and a repeat X-ray was obtained. Which statement is true?
options: The pneumothorax is now small and so the chest drain can be removed
The chest drain is incorrectly placed and should be removed
The chest drain is adequately positioned
The chest drain has pierced the right lung and should be removed
The chest drain should be replaced by a larger chest drain regardless of the clinical response
questions.correct_answer: The chest drain is adequately positioned
questions.learning_points:
The pneumothorax remains big. A pneumothorax is considered big if it is wider than 2 cm at the level of the hilum.
Although the tip of the tube is projected over the lung this does not mean that it has pierced the lung.

questions.question: 2 IMAGES: Image 1 - full-sized image. Image 2 - detail image. Patient with chest pain. Which statement is true?
options: Chest X-rays are not required routinely in the setting of clinically suspected uncomplicated rib fractures
There is no cause of chest pain demonstrated on these images
A normal chest X-ray excludes rib fractures
This image shows blunting of the left costophrenic angle indicating a haemothorax
The patient is rotated and so the image is non-diagnostic
questions.correct_answer: Chest X-rays are not required routinely in the setting of clinically suspected uncomplicated rib fractures
questions.learning_points:
Chest X-rays are not required routinely in the setting of uncomplicated clinically suspected rib fractures but can be requested if there is clinical suspicion of a complication such as a pneumothorax or haemothorax.
The detail image shows a rib fracture on the left.
The costophrenic angles are well-defined indicating there is no haemothorax.
Although the patient is a little rotated, a cause of chest pain – the rib fracture – is demonstrated so the image can be considered diagnostic.

questions.question: Smoker with weight loss, haemoptysis, and finger clubbing. The most likely diagnosis is...?
questions.learning_points:
There is a large left hilar mass which is most likely due to a bronchogenic carcinoma in this clinical context.
The clinical features do not point towards active infection, although on the grounds of the image alone this diagnosis should also be considered a possibility.
Sarcoidosis usually causes bilateral hilar enlargement.
Glioblastoma metastases outside the central nervous system is rare.

questions.question: What is the abnormality demonstrated radiological?
options: Breast asymmetry due to previous mastectomy
questions.learning_points:
This is the classic appearance of a pleural effusion. The ‘meniscus’ sign is present which should not be mistaken for a raised hemidiaphragm as in the case of a phrenic nerve palsy.
The right breast appears denser because of the fluid in the right pleural cavity.
There is no air bronchogram.
The hilar structures appear normal.
Note the sternotomy wires.

questions.question: Chest pain in patient with permanent pacemaker inserted 2 months previously. Which radiological finding is present?
options: Pacemaker insertion complicated by large pneumothorax
Left mid and lower zone consolidation
questions.correct_answer: Left mid and lower zone consolidation
questions.learning_points:
The pacemaker appears correctly positioned.
There is no pneumothorax.
Although the heart appears enlarged the heart size cannot be accurately assessed on an anterior-posterior (AP) image.
Consolidation is present in the left mid and lower zones; pneumonia was the cause of chest pain in this patient.

questions.question: Which artifact is seen on this chest X-ray detail image?
questions.learning_points:
You may not have come across this artifact before, but an understanding of anatomy helps to determine what it is.
The artifact is located outside the contour of the trachea and does not follow the contour of the aorta. It does not have the appearance of sternotomy wires (see questions 1 and 8).
Although the oesophagus is not visible on a chest X-ray this artifact follows its contour exactly. It is an oesophageal stent, placed to alleviate dysphagia related to an oesophageal tumour.
